analyzeResult.content:
Koruna Lidové noviny, 3 November 1994 SAVINGS AND INVESTMENT
NEW YORK STOCK EXCHANGE IS STILL THE LEADER
Trading in Shares of Foreign Companies Contributes to its Development
Despite the sharp increase in competition from stock exchanges in "old Europe", the stock exchange on Wall Street continues to be the largest institution of its type. This even despite the fact that its headquarters is located on possibly the narrowest street in New York. A visitor to the USA has access to all state institutions, and private institutions are also happy to "show off" for him. And the stock exchange is no exception. However, a visitor is allowed only into the visitors gallery, from where he can look down on the pit, where trading has been going on since 1903.
But on 24 October, Philip Morris, the fourth largest American company and the fifth largest in the world, was able to arrange, thanks to its great influence, the exceptional admittance of a group of Czech journalists to the pit itself. So we were able to get a taste of the singular atmosphere of large transactions, where thousands and even tens of thousands of shares change hands.
- Between individual transactions, Patrick E. Murphy, a broker from R.P.M. Securities, gave us some of his time. As he told us, his income is dependent on the profit he achieves. Last Monday, 30 minutes before the sound of the bell which punctuates the end of the session, he was having quite a successful day. He earned 120,000 USD just on shares in Grupo Televisia, S. A., the Mexican television company.
There would not be too much space for dancing in the pit of the stock exchange. Traders zip back and forth with pads of paper for confirming transactions in their hands, their pockets filled with pens. Thousands of scraps of paper littered the floor, and trash cans were filled with sandwich wrappers. It did not appear that the brokers have very long careers. Patrick is 34 years old, and he hopes that by the time he is 45 he will have earned enough money to leave the stock exchange. But there are exceptions, too, and the Nestor of the stock exchange is 72.
The New York Stock Exchange conducts trading in the shares of 2,361 companies, up from 1,543 ten years ago. Over the last decade, the stock exchange has experienced its greatest growth ever, adding 306 companies over the last year alone. Trading in shares of foreign companies is contributing to the development of the stock exchange. There are 37 countries represented on the exchange, from the Cayman
Islands to China, which has the shares of six companies in the trading. Czech companies are known in the exchange, too, but no particular names were mentioned. It is anticipated that the first Czech company should arrive on the exchange by the year 2000. At the present time, shares in the Czech and Slovak Investment Fund, which collects capital for investment in the CR, are quoted on the exchange. Philip Morris shares, of which there are nearly 592 million, are among the most traded shares. Shares of Telefonos de Mexico are among the top five, and this is clear proof of Americans interest in shares of foreign companies. Shares in IBM, which is perhaps the best known American company in our country, were in seventh place, with 457 million shares.
While we were with Patrick F. Murphy he took an order for 11,000 shares, and he had the look of a satisfied man. Perhaps his plans will work out, and we wished him luck as we were leaving. But at that moment, he was passing on instructions to his employees, so I do not know if he registered what we said.
(See attached page for table)
2046879162
